title: 114_hr1207
content: The Act is titled the "Healthy Fisheries through Better Science Act" and defines stock assessment. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act defines stock assessment as evaluating the past, present, and future status of a fish stock, including life history characteristics and fishing activities. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act defines stock assessment as evaluating the past, present, and future status of a fish stock, including life history characteristics and fishing activities. SEC. 3. STOCK ASSESSMENT PLAN. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act now requires the Secretary to develop and publish a stock assessment plan for all fish stocks covered by a fishery management plan. The plan must include a schedule for updating stock assessments based on the biology and characteristics of each stock. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act mandates the development of a stock assessment plan for all fish stocks in a fishery management plan. This plan includes updating stock assessments based on the biology and characteristics of each stock, requiring new assessments every 5 years or as specified by the Secretary. For stocks without previous assessments, an initial assessment schedule must be established. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act requires a stock assessment plan for all fish stocks in a fishery management plan. The plan includes updating assessments every 5 years or as specified by the Secretary. It also mandates an initial stock assessment within 3 years of the plan's publication, with a waiver option available. Data and analysis, especially for recreational fishing, are identified to improve future stock assessments. The Magnuson-Stevens Act requires stock assessment plans for fish stocks, with updates every 5 years. A waiver option exists if the Secretary deems an assessment unnecessary. The Secretary must issue the first stock assessment plan within 1 year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. IMPROVING SCIENCE. Incorporation of information from various sources is essential for effective fisheries management under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. This includes input from governmental and nongovernmental entities such as State and Federal agencies, fishermen, fishing communities, universities, and research institutions. The best scientific information available should be used to form conservation and management measures. Additionally, improvements in data collection and analysis are emphasized in the Act. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act emphasizes the incorporation of data from various sources, including fishermen, fishing communities, universities, and research institutions, into fisheries management decisions. The Secretary, in consultation with the science and statistical committee of the Councils, will develop guidelines to facilitate the use of reliable data and analysis for conservation purposes. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act requires the establishment of guidelines for collecting data, performing analyses, and creating a registry of data providers to reduce uncertainty in stock assessments. The Secretary and Regional Fishery Management Councils must use all data and analyses meeting these guidelines for decision-making purposes. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act mandates the use of best available scientific information for fisheries management decisions. The science and statistical committee of the Councils must explain how data and analyses were utilized in establishing conservation measures. If any data or analysis is not used, an explanation must be provided by the committee in the Federal Register notice. The Secretary of Commerce must develop and publish guidelines within 1 year of the enactment of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act for the use of scientific information in fisheries management decisions. Within 1 year of enactment, the Secretary of Commerce must submit a report to Congress on cost reduction in fishery management plans, including goals, methods like human observers and monitoring systems, cost-effectiveness, and explanations for not using cost-effective methods. SEC. 6. COST SHARING. Amends the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act to require the Secretary to prepare an analysis of costs recovered by fees before collecting any fees.
